questions.question_text: A cybersecurity analyst is reviewing Apache logs on a web server and finds that some logs are missing. The analyst has identified that the systems administrator accidentally deleted some log files. Which of the following actions or rules should be implemented to prevent this incident from reoccurring?

comments.content: This question also clearly states "prevent from reoccurring". A backup server is NOT going to prevent the incident from reoccurring. It's a mitigation control, sure, but it won't prevent it.
In addition to the things I have already mentioned, this also include the principle of "least privilege".

discussion.content:
This MUST be B:
From the Cybersecurity Analyst Certification Bundle: "As it applies to security, separation of duties might be used to prevent any single individual from disrupting business-critical processes, accessing sensitive data, or making untested administrative changes across an organization. For example, your organization might break down the requirements to delete sensitive data into several steps: verify, execute, and approve."
Separation of duties (B) is the correct answer as server owners should NOT have access to logs.

Personnel trg - the systems admin accidentally deleted the files. We can assume that the sys admin is aware that such should not have been deleted, so this would not be the answer
Mandatory vacay - easily eliminated
Backup server - Backing up the log files will not prevent this incident from reoccurring; it would only serve to mitigate/recover from the effects of accidentally deleting files 

Separation of duties - Consummating any business critical functions should be under the control of two or more individuals, to serve as check and balance (Verify, Execute, Approve). If, after deleting the files, the request had gone on for approval, the deletion would not have gone through.

B is the answer.
I think the answer should be B. Do not give permission to delete logs begin with.

comments.content: I agree, the only way to preventing this from happening is to limit the rights of this administrator so that even if he does it accidentally the logs dont get deleted. in short revolve the rights of the administrator to delete the logs

discussion.content: wrong. training somebody won't prevent them from accidentally deleting stuff.

comments.content: so backup server it is?
on the basis that backing up is the only one that truly prevents :)
A backup is not a preventive control. Backing up your web server does not prevent attacks. It helps you mitigate a successful attack against your webserver.

discussion.content: Agreed, especially when it says "how can this be prevented" rather than be remediated
I'd say A. The most simply answer would be to teach him not to accidentally delete files.

comments.content: yeah personnel training it is. Or have the log files be sent to a central location

discussion.content: I don't think D is an answer. I would have gone with B

comments.content: read well my friend, the incident here is the deletion of files, back up server will not help files from being deleted by a user, i would say that is more like a compensating control imo. for this i would go with B , separation of duties would define the access to be granted to different individuals

This made sense we seem to be overcomplicating the situation. An "Accident" will happen and cannot be prevented perfectly. in the event the Accident happens again the fact is we still need to recover the logs
D is correct because it is the only way the problem would be prevented. The rest only minimise likeliness

choices.D: Install security software and a host-based firewall on the SCADA equipment.
choices.C: Update the firewall rules to block SCADA network access from those laptop IP addresses.
choices.B: Require connections to the SCADA network to go through a forwarding proxy.
choices.A: Implement a group policy on company systems to block access to SCADA networks.

comments.content: Shouldn't be A. There needs to be an IPSEC peer on the other end and we don't see where the SCADA systems are running IPSEC.

discussion.content:
I think A is correct, you can block traffic using GPOs

https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/813878/how-to-block-specific-network-protocols-and-ports-by-using-ipsec
The answer is A, don't forget that the question says "random" laptops. Blocking IPs won't be the solution.
Does GPO apply for Linux or MAC systems to block this traffic?
I wouldn’t go with C since it is mentioned that firewall rules are already in place

comments.content: And C kind of caters to “only those ip addresses” while question mentions random
That said, the question is "ORIGINATING from company laptops"... . The wording in these questions is a bitch.

discussion.content: This is definitely not A. GPOs are not even mentioned in NIST (https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-82r2.pdf). I'm fairly confident it's C.

comments.content: i would go with C as it mentions specifically only those laptops to be blocked...

discussion.content: Is GPO really capable to block access to specific networks?

questions.question_text: While reviewing three months of logs, a security analyst notices probes from random company laptops going to SCADA equipment at the company's manufacturing location. Some of the probes are getting responses from the equipment even though firewall rules are in place, which should block this type of unauthorized activity. Which of the following should the analyst recommend to keep this activity from originating from company laptops?
An analyst is preparing for a technical security compliance check on all Apache servers. Which of the following will be the BEST to use?

discussion.content: This question is on the exam.

comments.content: Did you clear the exam
Any of those questions might be on the exam, that's the purpose of this page to show all available questions that might appear there

discussion.content: This question was on the exam (october-2020)

A. CIS. "CIS develops their own Configuration Policy Benchmarks, or CIS benchmarks, that allow organizations to improve their security and compliance programs and posture".
B. Nagios - Monitoring tool
C. OWASP -"The WSTG is a comprehensive guide to testing the security of web applications and web services." https://owasp.org/www-project-web-security-testing-guide/
D. Untidy - NO. It is a fuzzing tool
E. Cain & Abel - NO. It is a password cracker

So I am between A or C. C looks to be more specific to Apache.
Although wording of "technical security compliance check" might suggest A..

comments.content:
also this one here might suggest option A - CIS benchmark
https://www.cisecurity.org/benchmark/apache_http_server/

discussion.content: I thought this would be C

choices.C: Expired DNS entries on users' devices. Request the affected users perform a DNS flush.
choices.A: The access point is blocking access by MAC address. Disable MAC address filtering.
choices.B: The network is not available. Escalate the issue to network support.
choices.D: The access point is a rogue device. Follow incident response procedures.

comments.content: I assume they have some type of connectivity because the only thing they cannot reach are internal resources. That pushed me to rogue AP.
the scenario is assuming perfect implementation from the company. hence only explanation is evil twin. That's my take on it
yeah possible but the question didnt even give hint. not that saw
Almost none lol. But my instinct is telling me that this is an evil twin attack.

discussion.content: what elements in the question lead it to D instead of B?

questions.question_text: A company provides wireless connectivity to the internal network from all physical locations for company-owned devices. Users were able to connect the day before, but now all users have reported that when they connect to an access point in the conference room, they cannot access company resources. Which of the following BEST describes the cause of the problem?

A security analyst received an alert from the antivirus software identifying a complex instance of malware on a company's network. The company does not have the resources to fully analyze the malware and determine its effect on the system. Which of the following is the BEST action to take in the incident recovery and post-incident response process?

choices.B: Detect and analyze the precursors and indicators; schedule a lessons learned meeting.
choices.D: Perform event correlation; create a log retention policy.
choices.C: Remove the malware and inappropriate materials; eradicate the incident.
choices.A: Wipe hard drives, reimage the systems, and return the affected systems to ready state.

discussion.content: If the company can't fully analyze the malware, then they can't remove and eradicate the malware without leaving any remnants. So, best way is to wipe hard drives and reimage systems. Best answer is letter A.

comments.content:
Yes but Eradication - at least the way it is explained in my course material - includes all those steps:

"Eradication

Once the incident is contained, we turn our attention to the eradication process, in which we return all systems to a known-good state. It is important to gather evidence before we recover systems because in many cases we won’t know that we need legally admissible evidence until days, weeks, or even months after an incident. It pays, then, to treat each incident as if it will eventually end up in a court of justice.
Once all relevant evidence is captured, we fix all that was broken. The aim is to restore full, trustworthy functionality to the organization. For hosts that were compromised, the best practice is to simply reinstall the system from a gold master image and then restore data from the most recent backup that occurred prior to the attack."

Here is some more information:
https://resources.infosecinstitute.com/category/certifications-training/cysa-plus/cysa-plus-knowledge-domains/cysa-plus-domain-incident-recovery-post-incident-response-process/
And
https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-61r2.pdf

discussion.content: A : Because in this answer only it covers " BEST action to take in the incident recovery and post-incident response process "
A is more suitable for the recovery and post incident process. C is more eradication phase

A is best Answer. The question as whats best action to take in Incident Recovery and Post Incident Response. According to the NIST checklist, Returning a System to an Operational Ready State is a part of the Incident Recovery Phase. Removing Malware and inappropriate material; Eradicating the Incident, is a part of the Incident Eradication Phase, which comes before Incident Recovery. The answer should be A.
